title-group.article-title: An Extreme Value Approach to Estimating Volatility and Valueat Risk*

abstract.p: This article determines the type of asymptotic distribution for the extreme changes in U.S. Treasury yields. The thin‐tailed Gumbel and exponential distributions are strongly rejected against the fat‐tailed Frechet and Pareto distributions. The empirical results indicate that the volatility of maximal and minimal changes in interest rates declines as time‐to‐maturity rises, yielding a downward‐sloping volatility curve for the extremes. The article proposes an extreme value approach to estimating value at risk and shows that the statistical theory of extremes provides a more accurate approach for risk management and value at risk (VaR) calculations than the standard models.

sec.label: I.
sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The default‐free short‐term interest rate driving the changes in the entire term structure is fundamental to the classical approach to pricing fixed income securities and derivatives. Both equilibrium and arbitrage‐free term structure models use the short rate and its estimated volatility as inputs to determine the value of interest rate contingent claims. This makes the accurate estimation of the level and volatility of interest rate changes crucial to pricing interest rate derivatives. Given these facts, many researchers in recent years have been inclined to model and estimate the conditional distribution of interest rates. The methods based on a parametric distribution assume that the interest rate change is normally distributed. However, there is now strong evidence that interest rate changes are not normally distributed.1The tails of the empirical distribution appear to be thicker than the tails of the normal distribution, which means that large interest rate changes actually occur more frequently than predicted by the unconditional normal model.

A major issue in estimating the term structure of interest rate volatility is the modeling of the distribution of interest rates. In practice, the empirical distribution is difficult to handle, and a parametric model is often preferred. However, since there is no theoretical model for exact distribution, an assumption has to be made. The method used in this article is based on “extreme value theory.” The volatility of interest rate changes is estimated using the extremes of the short rate process. Focusing on the extreme interest rate changes, rather than the interest rate changes generally, allows avoidance of the difficult choice of a distribution for interest rates. The article makes a contribution to the literature by providing a new approach—based on extreme value theory—to estimating the term structure of interest rate volatility.

For the last 2 decades, an enormous amount of work has been directed toward modeling and estimation of financial time series. However, most of the empirical studies and models concern average properties like expected returns, volatility, or correlations, and little attention has been given to the extreme movements themselves. Limited work has been done mostly to explain the extreme movements of stock prices, and almost no empirical study has been presented to analyze the mean and volatility of extreme changes in short‐term interest rates.2The present study, to our knowledge, represents the first estimation of the asymptotic distribution of short rate changes during large falls and rises in the interest rate market. We assume that during the extreme price or interest rate movements in financial markets (like interest rate or stock market booms and crashes) what is of interest to market participants is not how much the interest rates change from one day to another, or what happens to this daily volatility. Instead what market participants are concerned with are the mean and volatility of short rate changes at the extreme tails of the distribution.

The article examines the asymptotic behavior of extreme changes in the U.S. Treasury securities market from the mid 1950s through the end of 1998. The maximal and minimal values are obtained from the daily observations for the 3‐month, 6‐month, 1‐year, and 10‐year Treasury yields. The term structure of interest rate volatility in extreme values is obtained by using the parameter estimates of the extreme value distributions. The empirical results indicate that the volatility of maximal and minimal changes in interest rates declines as time‐to‐maturity rises, yielding a downward‐sloping volatility curve for the extremes. For all data sets and for all asymptotic distributions used, the estimated volatility of minimal changes is found to be greater than that of the maximal changes.

This study determines the type of asymptotic distribution for the extreme changes in Treasury yields. Two classes of extreme value distributions are used to find the correct limit distributions for maxima and minima. The first class, proposed by Jenkinson (1955), encompasses the three standard extreme value distributions: Frechet, Weibull, and Gumbel. The second class, called the generalized Pareto distribution, nests the Pareto, uniform, and exponential distributions. According to the statistical test results, the thin‐tailed Gumbel and exponential distributions with rapidly decreasing tails are strongly rejected against the fat‐tailed Frechet and Pareto distributions with slowly decreasing tails. The results are found to be robust across different interest rate series.

Current risk management practices rely, first, on estimation of appropriate volatility of risk factors and, then, on calculation of the implied changes in value at risk (VaR). We investigate whether we can obtain a more satisfactory approach by using extreme value theory. In standard VaR models, risk factors are assumed to be normally distributed, and the estimated volatility parameter of the normal distribution yields the threshold that can be used in VaR calculations. However, the existing literature on interest rates, exchange rates, and stock returns provides strong evidence that the distribution of changes in these risk factors is heavily and significantly non‐Gaussian. Under these conditions, we think that an alternative approach that approximates the tail areas asymptotically may be more appropriate than imposing an explicit functional form like the normal or lognormal on the distribution.

We propose an extreme value approach to estimating value at risk and show that the statistical theory of extremes provides some assistance in improving the traditional VaR models. The new approach puts more emphasis on the tail areas of the observed frequency distributions and, hence, yields a more precise estimate for the thresholds in question. The empirical results based on the daily Treasury yields indicate that the generalized extreme value distributions perform surprisingly well in capturing both the rate of occurrence and the (average) extent of extreme events in interest rate markets. In fact, statistical theory of extremes appears to be a more natural and robust approach to risk management calculations.

The article is organized as follows.Section IIpresents extreme value theory and the statistical estimation procedures for extremes.Section IIIintroduces an extreme value approach to calculating value at risk.Section IVdescribes the data.Section Vprovides the estimation results.Section VIpresents the value at risk calculations.Section VIIconcludes.

Notable exceptions that use extreme value approach to explain the fluctuations of financial time series are Rothschild and Stiglitz (1970), who use the weight of the tails of two random variables to propose a better definition of increasing risk than the usual variance; Parkinson (1980), who finds that extremes could contain information useful for a more efficient estimation of the volatility; De Haan et al. (1989), who show that if the change in stock price follows an ARCH process introduced by Engle (1982), then the maximum has a Frechet distribution; Jansen and de Vries (1991), who use extremes to investigate the fatness of the distribution tails; Loretan and Phillips (1994), who use the extremal index for testing the covariance stationarity of time series; Longin (1996), who examines the extreme movements of the U.S. stock market, and shows empirically that the extreme returns obey a Frechet distribution; Danielsson and de Vries (1997a ), who study the improvement of conventional tail index and quantile estimator by incorporating an estimate of the second‐order term of the tail expansion.

sec.label: III.
sec.title: An Extreme Value Approach to Calculating Value at Risk
sec.p: In the last few years, value at risk (VaR) has become a very popular risk management tool in many different types of organizations.11A VaR model measures market risk by determining how much the value of a portfolio could decline over a given probability as a result of changes in market prices or rates.12For example, if the given period of time is 1 day and the given probability is 1%, the VaR measure would be an estimate of the decline in the portfolio value that could occur with a 1% probability over the next trading day. In other words, if the VaR measure is accurate, losses greater than the VaR measure should occur less than 1% of the time.

The most commonly used VaR models assume that the probability distribution of the daily changes in each market variable is normal, an assumption that is far from perfect.13The changes in many variables exhibit significant amounts of excess kurtosis. This means that the probability distributions of daily changes in these variables have “fat tails” so that extreme outcomes happen much more frequently than would be predicted by the normal distribution assumption. In this article, we show how the normal distribution assumption can be relaxed. We propose an extreme value approach to calculating VaR that allows the user to choose more generalized fat‐tailed distributions for the daily changes in each market variable.

sec.label: IV.
sec.title: Data
sec.p: The data sets used in this study are obtained from the Federal Reserve H.15 database and consist of daily observations for the annualized yields on 3‐month, 6‐month, 1‐year, and 10‐year U.S. Treasury securities. The time period of investigation for the 3‐month Treasury bills extends from January 8, 1954, through December 25, 1998, for a total of 11,237 daily observations. The daily data for the 6‐month T‐bill rates cover the period from December 12, 1958, to December 25, 1998, yielding 9,997 daily observations. The data for the 1‐year Treasury bills consist of 9,846 annualized yields from July 17, 1959, to December 25, 1998. The database on the 10‐year Treasury includes 9,231 daily yields over the period January 2, 1962–December 31, 1998.14The unconditional means of interest rate changes are very close to zero. The unconditional standard deviations of the daily changes in 3‐month, 6‐month, 1‐year, and 10‐year Treasury yields are about 0.101%, 0.094%, 0.084%, and 0.069%, yielding a downward‐sloping volatility curve. The excess kurtosis statistics for daily changes in 3‐month, 6‐month, 1‐year, and 10‐year Treasury yields are 28.81 (0.046), 24.62 (0.048), 19.20 (0.049), and 14.02 (0.051), with standard errors in parentheses. This clearly indicates that the tails of the distribution of interest rate changes are much thicker than the tails of the normal distribution.

In this article, extreme values are defined as excesses over high thresholds. The interest rate changes below the threshold are called the minimal changes, and those above the threshold are called the maximal changes. We set the threshold as two standard deviations around the sample mean of the interest rate change, which corresponds to almost 2% of the right and left tails of the distribution. This yields 244 (243), 217 (211), 204 (215), and 230 (229) minimal (maximal) values for the 3‐month, 6‐month, 1‐year, and 10‐year Treasury. The absolute values of the unconditional means of extremes are about 0.37%, 0.35%, 0.30%, and 0.22%, respectively. The unconditional standard deviations of both the maxima and minima are in the range of 0.10%–0.30%.

fn.p: The unconditional average levels of the 3‐month, 6‐month, 1‐year, and 10‐year Treasury yields for the common sample are about 6.20%, 6.35%, 6.40%, and 7.58%, implying an upward‐sloping yield curve. The unconditional standard deviations are about 2.62%, 2.56%, 2.42%, and 2.50%, respectively. The excess kurtosis values for interest rate levels are found to be between 3.49 and 5.13, and they are statistically different from zero, implying that the distributions of interest rate levels have fat tails compared to the normal distribution.

sec.label: V.
sec.title: Estimation Results
sec.p:
Table 1presents the maximum likelihood estimates of the generalized extreme value (GEV) and Gumbel distributions. The empirical results are clear‐cut and allow one to determine unambiguously the type of extreme value distribution: for both the largest falls and rises of the 3‐month, 6‐month, 1‐year, and 10‐year Treasury yields, the asymptotic distribution belongs to the domain of attraction of the Frechet distribution. In all cases, the tail index ξ is estimated to be positive and statistically different from zero. For the maximum changes in interest rates, the estimated tail index is found to be in the range of 0.41–0.54, while for the minimum changes, the estimate of ξ varies from 0.27 to 0.31. A likelihood ratio (LR) test between the Frechet case and Gumbel case leads to a firm rejection of the Gumbel distribution (and a fortiori a rejection of the Weibull distribution).15

The maximum likelihood estimates of the GEV distribution show that the volatility of maximal and minimal changes, measured by the scale parameters σmaxand σmin, declines as time‐to‐maturity rises, producing a downward‐sloping volatility curve for the extremes. More specifically, the volatility of the maxima for the GEV decreases from 0.071% to 0.029%, whereas for the minima, it reduces from 0.079% to 0.036% as time‐to‐maturity increases from 3 months to 10 years. The estimated volatility of minimal changes is greater than that of the maximal changes.16A comparison of the estimated scale parameters of the GEV and Gumbel distributions indicates that the volatility is overestimated when the extremes are drawn from the Gumbel distribution. As shown intable 1, the estimates of σmaxfor the Gumbel fall from 0.103% to 0.039% for the maxima, while for the minima, the volatility estimates decrease from 0.106% to 0.044% as time‐to‐maturity rises from 3 months to 10 years. The results indicate that the volatility curves for the extremes are downward‐sloping, and the minimum changes in Treasury yields are more volatile than the maximum changes.

Table 2shows the maximum likelihood parameter estimates of the generalized Pareto and exponential distributions, asymptotict‐statistics, and the maximized log likelihood values for the extreme changes in 3‐month, 6‐month, 1‐year, and 10‐year Treasury yields. According to the asymptotict‐statistics given intable 2, the parameters of the GPD and exponential distribution are statistically significant at the 1% level. The estimated shape parameters for the maximal values (ξmax) for all data sets are greater than those for the minimal values (ξmin). The estimates of the shape parameter for the maximum changes in Treasury yields lie in the range of 0.21 to 0.45, while the corresponding values for the minimum changes are found to be between 0.20 and 0.36. The maximized log‐likelihood values for all data sets are much greater for the GPD distribution than for the exponential distribution, which restricts the tail index at zero. For both the maxima and minima of interest rate changes, the volatility of extremes decreases with increase in time‐to‐maturity. This implies the presence of downward‐sloping term structure of interest rate volatility during the extreme movements of the U.S. Treasury market. The estimates of σmaxfor the GPD decrease from 0.077% to 0.040% as time‐to‐maturity rises from 3 months to 10 years. Whereas, for the same times‐to‐maturity, the volatility estimates for the minimum interest rate changes, σmin, decline from 0.080% to 0.043%. As in the case of the GEV distribution, the estimated volatility of minimal values turns out to be higher than that of the maximal values for the GPD. Maximum likelihood estimation of the exponential distribution yields a downward‐sloping volatility curve, and again the volatility of minimal changes is greater than that of the maximal changes for all times‐to‐maturity. In other words, setting the tail index at zero does not affect our conclusions except for the magnitudes of the volatilities. The σmaxestimates are in the range of 0.050%–0.126%, while the volatilities for the minima, σmin, are estimated to between 0.057% and 0.132%.

sec.label: VI.
sec.title: Value at Risk Calculations
sec.p: Our main objective is to obtain estimates of the threshold Ψ for the GPD and GEV distributions and then compare these with the thresholds generated by the standard approach that uses the normal distribution. The ΨGPDand ΨGEVgiven in equations(31)and(32)are calculated using the maximum likelihood and regression method estimates of μmax, σmax, and ξmax. The Ψnormalgiven in equation(22)is computed using the standard deviation of daily changes in interest rates.

Assuming that the daily changes in Treasury yields,X, are normally distributed, the volatility parameter for the original interest rate data is estimated by maximizing the log‐likelihood function,
For all Treasury yields considered in the article, the estimated mean of short rate changes, μ, is found to be almost zero and statistically insignificant. The standard deviations of daily changes in 3‐month, 6‐month, 1‐year, and 10‐year Treasury are estimated to be 0.101%, 0.093%, 0.084%, and 0.069%, respectively. It is important to note that this commonly used VaR model does not allow for asymmetries in calculating thresholds since the positive and negative tails of the normal distribution are identical. In other words, the standard VaR approach yields the same thresholds for the maximal and minimal changes in risk factors. One advantage of the asymptotic theory of extremes is that asymmetries in the positive and negative tails of the distribution can easily be handled since the extreme value approach developed here separates sudden drops from sudden jumps. This allows us to test whether the two tails are indeed symmetric.

The estimated thresholds for the GPD, GEV, and normal distributions as well as the multiplication factors (ΨGPD/Ψnormaland ΨGEV/Ψnormal) are presented intable 5. The results show that the extreme tails yield threshold points, ΨGPDand ΨGEV, that are up to 38% higher than the thresholds, Ψnormal, one obtains with the standard approach.18 Table 5shows that the ΨGPDand ΨGEVlevels decrease as time‐to‐maturity rises, indicating that short‐term interest rates have more pronounced nonnormal tails than do long rates. For all Treasury yields, both the ΨGPDand ΨGEVare found to be higher for the extreme negative increments than for the extreme positive increments, implying that drops seem to have tail areas farther away from normal. For example, for the regression method estimates, the multiplication factors are found to be in the range of 1.24 to 1.28 for the maximal changes, whereas they range from 1.29 to 1.38 for the minimal changes. According to a controversial item in the Bank for International Settlements (BIS) guidelines, financial institutions are required by BIS to calculate a 99% upper bound for their daily losses due to market risk and then are required to multiply this figure by at least 3. This multiplication factor is justified essentially by the observed non‐Gaussian nature of frequency distributions. The new VaR model proposed here is potentially more precise and yields a more satisfactory estimate for this factor. Based on the VaR estimates intable 5, the BIS multiplication factor of 3 seems to be excessive since the extreme value approach implies a 24%–38% greater VaR than the traditional approach.

So far, the estimates indicate that the tail areas obtained from extremal theory are quite different from and potentially more useful than the tails obtained with the standard approach. The implied value at risk estimates are consequently different as well. Yet, the real test for a theory is not that it is different from the alternatives, but whether it is any better according to some specific criteria. We provide evidence that the use of extreme value distributions may represent a significant improvement over the standard VaR estimates. The question that we ask is related to the relative performance of VaR numbers calculated from the extreme value distributions. Note that we estimate the parameters of the extreme value distributions using almost 2% tail observations and then calculate the 1% VaRs. If the new approach is superior to the current alternatives, the standard VaR model should actually leave more than 1% of the observations beyond the threshold, while the extreme value method should capture 1% of the observations more closely. Thus, we compare the relative performance of the extreme value approach with the alternative of using the normal distribution.

Table 6presents the number of observations that fall in the 1% tails of the GPD, GEV, and normal distributions. The results show the normal distribution to be quite inadequate for determining a 1% threshold for market risk factors. In fact, given that we have 11,236, 9,996, 9,845, and 9,230 daily observations for the 3‐month, 6‐month, 1‐year, and 10‐year Treasury yields, we would expect approximately 112, 100, 98, and 92 observations to fall into each 1% tail. Yet, on average, 1% tails estimated from the normal distribution include 188 observations for the 3‐month, 184 observations for the 6‐month and 1‐year, and 174 observations for the 10‐year Treasury yields. The VaR estimates of the traditional approach thus imply the mean absolute percentage error (MAE%) of 67%, 84%, 88%, and 89% for the 3‐month, 6‐month, 1‐year, and 10‐year Treasury yields, respectively. According totable 6, the 1% tails from the regression method estimates of the GPD capture, respectively, 115, 106, 103, and 94 observations and of the GEV capture 111 observations for the 3‐month, and 103 observations for the 6‐month and 1‐year, and 98 observations for the 10‐year Treasury. In other words, the new VaR model produces very low mean absolute percentage errors. Using the feasible generalized least squares method described in Ait‐Sahalia (1996b , pp. 409–10), we estimate the parameters of the spot rate process for the 3‐month and 10‐year Treasury yields.20Based on these estimated parameters, the model is simulated into the future to compute the prices of discount bonds of different maturities. These prices are then turned into yields and the extreme changes in simulated yields are obtained to calculate value at risk. Given the interest rate model in(35), the price of a zero‐coupon bond with a payoff of $1 at timeT,P(r,t,T), can be written in the form
where the expectation in(36)can be calculated numerically using Monte Carlo simulation. This entails repeatedly simulating paths for the interest rate process using a discrete version of the interest rate dynamics described in(35), calculating the integral inside the expectation in(36)for each path, and averaging over the values obtained for each path to obtain an estimate ofP(r,t,T).

We simulate each observation of 3‐month T‐bill rates for 6 and 12 months into the future to create 11,237 daily yields from January 8, 1954, to December 25, 1998. Similarly, each daily yield on the 10‐year Treasury is simulated for 10 and 20 years into the future to generate 9,231 daily yields from January 2, 1962, to December 31, 1998. In performing the simulations here, the stochastic process in(35)is discretized into daily intervals by assuming 250 days in a year. Each numerical estimate is based on 10,000 simulation trials. To reduce the simulation variance, the antithetic variable technique is employed.21Although not presented in the article, the nonlinear short rate models produce in simulations the types of extremes that are observed in the data. The extreme positive and negative increments in the simulated series are observed almost at the same time as those that occurred in the actual series. A notable point is that the magnitude of extreme values of the simulated series turns out to be slightly greater than the magnitude of actual extremes.

sec.label: VII.
sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This article determines the type of asymptotic distribution for the extreme changes in U.S. Treasury yields. To find the correct limit distributions for maxima and minima, the likelihood ratio test is performed between the Frechet and Gumbel distributions as well as between the Pareto and exponential distributions. The thin‐tailed Gumbel and exponential distributions with rapidly decreasing tails are strongly rejected against the fat‐tailed Frechet and Pareto distributions with slowly decreasing tails. The results clearly indicate that the extremes are not normally distributed.

Despite a bewildering array of deterministic and stochastic volatility models, relatively little is known about the dynamics of short‐term interest rate volatility in extreme values. One of the objectives of this article is to estimate the term structure of interest rate volatility during the extreme movements of the U.S. Treasury securities market. A major issue in estimating the term structure of interest rate volatility is the modeling of the distribution of interest rates. Most of the existing interest rate models, which use a method based on a parametric distribution, assume that short‐term interest rate changes are normally distributed. However, this study clearly shows that the tails of the empirical distribution are much thicker than the tails of the normal distribution. The method used here to estimate volatility is based on the extreme value theory. The volatility of extreme interest rate changes declines as time‐to‐maturity rises, yielding a downward‐sloping volatility curve for the extremes. For all data sets and for all asymptotic distributions used, the volatility curve for the minima plots above the volatility curve for the maxima, implying that the minimal changes are more volatile than the maximal changes for all times‐to‐maturity.

The article emphasizes that the statistical theory of extremes provides a more accurate approach for risk management and value at risk calculations. The results show that the extreme value theory and the implied tail estimation produce a more useful framework for VaR calculations. The 1‐day ninety‐ninth percentile VaR measure is found to be 24%–38% greater if one uses the extreme tails rather than following the standard approach of using the normal distribution. The relative performance of the extreme value and traditional approaches is compared. The empirical results indicate that the VaRs calculated using the tails of extreme value distributions are significantly more precise than the standard approach. The VaR tails are found to be more robust and yield more accurate estimates of the rate of occurrence and the size of extreme observations.
